Cost Comparison

Dental Schools vs Private Dentists: Save 50-70% on Care

January 13, 2025
10 min read
By Dental Guide Team

Discover how dental schools can save you thousands on dental care. Learn what to expect, how to find schools near you, and which procedures are best for dental school clinics.

The Hidden Secret of Affordable Dental Care

If you need dental work but can't afford private practice prices, dental schools might be your answer. Across the United States, 71 accredited dental schools offer quality care at 50-70% below typical prices.

Yet most people don't even know this option exists. They either go into debt, put off needed treatment, or suffer with dental problems. This guide will help you understand how dental schools work, what they cost, and whether they're right for you.

Why Are Dental Schools So Much Cheaper?

Dental schools operate under a different model than private practices. Their primary mission is education, not profit. Here's why they can charge so much less:

  • Student labor: Dental students perform procedures (under supervision) as part of their training
  • Non-profit status: Most schools are affiliated with universities and operate on a cost-recovery basis
  • Bulk pricing: Schools purchase supplies in large quantities at discounted rates
  • No marketing costs: They don't spend money on advertising

Price Comparison: Private Practice vs. Dental School

The savings can be dramatic. Here's a realistic comparison of what you might pay:

Procedure Private Practice Dental School You Save
Routine Cleaning $120 $45 63%
Composite Filling (1 surface) $200 $75 63%
Root Canal (front tooth) $900 $350 61%
Extraction (simple) $200 $75 63%
Full Denture (upper or lower) $2,000 $600 70%
Dental Crown $1,200 $500 58%

Real Savings Example:

A patient needing a root canal, crown, and two fillings might pay $2,800 at a private practice. The same work at a dental school could cost around $1,050‚Äîsaving over $1,700.

Is Dental School Care Safe?

This is the most common question. The short answer: Yes, dental school care is safe and high-quality. Here's why:

  • Licensed supervision: Every procedure is overseen by licensed dentists who are faculty members
  • Step-by-step approval: Students must get instructor approval at each stage of treatment
  • Modern equipment: Dental schools use current technology and techniques
  • Double-checked work: Faculty check all work before you leave

The Trade-Off:

The quality is excellent, but appointments take longer. What takes an hour in private practice might take 2-3 hours at a dental school because students work carefully and are checked by instructors.

What to Expect at a Dental School

1. The Screening Appointment

Before becoming a patient, you'll need a screening exam (usually $50-150). The school will:

  • Take X-rays and examine your teeth
  • Determine if your case fits their teaching needs
  • Assign you an appropriate student (based on their training level)
  • Create a treatment plan with estimated costs

Note: Not everyone is accepted. If your case is too complex or too simple, they may refer you elsewhere.

2. Longer Appointments

Plan for 2-4 hours per appointment. Students work slowly and carefully, and must wait for instructor approval between steps. Bring something to read or headphones for music.

3. Multiple Visits

What might take 2-3 visits in private practice could take 5-8 visits at a dental school. Factor this into your decision if you're traveling far or taking time off work.

4. Strict Attendance Policies

Dental schools have strict policies about missed appointments. Students have graduation requirements, and cancelations can delay their progress. Give plenty of notice if you need to reschedule.

Best Procedures for Dental Schools

Some procedures are great for dental schools. Others might be better done in private practice. Here's what works best:

Excellent for Dental Schools:

  • Routine cleanings and exams
  • Fillings (most types)
  • Simple extractions
  • Root canals
  • Crowns and bridges
  • Dentures (full and partial)
  • Deep cleanings (periodontal treatment)

Consider Private Practice Instead:

  • Emergency same-day care
  • Simple quick procedures (time/value may not be worth the travel)
  • Very complex surgical cases
  • Sedation dentistry (not all schools offer this)

How to Find Dental Schools Near You

There are 71 accredited dental schools across the United States. Use our free School Finder tool to locate the ones nearest to you.

Major Dental Schools by Region

Northeast: Harvard, NYU, Boston University, University of Pennsylvania, Rutgers, UConn

Southeast: University of Maryland, UNC Chapel Hill, MUSC, UF, VCU, East Carolina

Midwest: University of Michigan, Ohio State, University of Illinois, Marquette, Creighton

South: UT Health San Antonio, Texas A&M, Baylor, Oklahoma, LSU

West: UCSF, UCLA, USC, University of Washington, Oregon Health Sciences, University of Colorado

Dental Hygiene Schools: Even Cheaper

Don't forget dental hygiene programs! Community colleges and technical schools with hygiene programs offer:

  • Cleanings for $20-40
  • X-rays for $15-30
  • Exams for $10-25

Search "dental hygiene clinic near me" to find these programs. They're everywhere and significantly cheaper than dental schools for basic preventive care.

Tips for Success

  • Call early: Popular schools have waiting lists of 3-6 months
  • Be flexible: Taking appointments during less popular times (mornings, weekdays) can get you in faster
  • Ask about fees: Get a written estimate before starting treatment
  • Plan for the long haul: Commit to the full treatment schedule
  • Be patient: Remember, students are learning. Kindness goes a long way

Is a Dental School Right for You?

Consider a dental school if:

  • You need significant dental work and cost is a major factor
  • You have flexible schedule and can attend longer appointments
  • You're patient and understanding of students learning
  • You live near a dental school or can travel

Consider private practice if:

  • You need emergency or same-day care
  • Your time is extremely valuable
  • You need complex surgery or specialized care
  • You prefer minimal appointment visits

Bottom Line

Dental schools offer quality care at a fraction of the price. Yes, appointments take longer, but the savings can be thousands of dollars. For uninsured Americans or those with high deductibles, they're often the best option for major dental work.

Ready to find a dental school near you? Use our free School Finder tool to locate accredited programs in your area.
